cells (tracheids or vessel elements) or phloem sieve tube elements of a plant.
The xylem cells transport water and nutrients throughout the plant. Plant sap is
not to be confused with latex or resin; it is a separate substance, separately
produced, and with different components and functions.

'Xylem sap' consists primarily of a watery solution of hormones, mineral
elements and other nutrients. Transport of sap in xylem is characterized by
movement from the roots toward the leaves. Over the past century, there has
been some controversy regarding the mechanism of xylem sap transport; today,
most plant scientists agree that the cohesion-tension theory best explains
this process.

'Phloem sap' consists primarily of water, with sugars, hormones, and mineral
elements dissolved in it. It flows from where carbohydrates are produced or
stored to where they are used. The pressure flow hypothesis proposes a mechanism
for phloem sap transport. '']]

Maple syrup is made from reduced sugar maple xylem sap. The sap often is
harvested from the Sugar Maple, Acer saccharum.

In some countries (e.g., Russia, Latvia, Estonia or Finland) harvesting the
early spring sap of birch trees (so called "birch juice") for human consumption
is common practice; the sap can be used fresh or fermented and contains xylitol.
